NewWords.WordPhrase: a. taking great care to avoid danger 谨慎的
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. The bank is very cautious about lending money.

NewWords.WordPhrase: vt. show (esp. a feeling or quality) 流露;显示;展示  n. an act of showing sth.
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. She displayed great self-control when they told her the news.

NewWords.WordPhrase: vt. go with 陪伴，陪同
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. Let me accompany you to your hotel.

NewWords.WordPhrase: vt. display 展示  n. 展品
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. The new cars were proudly exhibited in the showroom window.
e.g. This painting is fairly typical of his early work.
e.g. Stop acting like a baby! Pull yourself together!
e.g. They purchased life at the expense of honor.

NewWords.WordPhrase: ad.，conj. however; in spite of that 然而; 虽然如此
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. He was angry; nevertheless, he listened to me.
e.g. Did the children take to their new teacher?

NewWords.WordPhrase: a. extremely impressive and attractive; excellent 宏大的，壮观的;出色的
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. The royal wedding was a magnificent occasion.

NewWords.WordPhrase: make (sth.) clear and easy to understand 阐明
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. Does this information shed any light on the problem?
e.g. He indicated his willingness with a nod of his head.

NewWords.WordPhrase: v. see and notice; watch carefully 观察;注意
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. Did you observe anything unusual in his behavior?

NewWords.WordPhrase: vt. make (sb.) feel suddenly frightened or worried 使惊慌，使恐慌 n. 惊慌，恐慌;警报
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. The government is alarmed by the dramatic increase in violent crime.

NewWords.WordPhrase: vt. refuse to accept 拒绝接受
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. He was rejected for the army because of his bad eyesight.
